The original plan for the millions of civilians displaced as a result of World War II was to repatriate them to their countries of origin as quickly as possible. Depending on [[Allied Occupation Zones in Germany|sectors occupied]] in [[Austria]] and [[Germany]], [[United States|American]], [[France|French]], [[United Kingdom|British]], or [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] forces tended to the immediate needs of the refugees and set in motion plans for repatriation. There may have been as many as 11 million displaced persons in Europe immediately followint the capitulation of the [[Third Reich]].
+
The original plan for the millions of civilians displaced as a result of World War II was to repatriate them to their countries of origin as quickly as possible. Depending on [[Allied Occupation Zones in Germany|sectors occupied]] in [[Austria]] and [[Germany]], [[United States|American]], [[France|French]], [[United Kingdom|British]], or [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] forces tended to the immediate needs of the refugees and set in motion plans for repatriation. There may have been as many as 11 million displaced persons in Europe immediately following the capitulation of the [[Third Reich]].
Estimates for displaced persons do not typically include several million ethnic Germans in Eastern Europe who were expelled and repatriated in Germany. See [[German exodus from Eastern Europe]].
Estimates for displaced persons do not typically include several million ethnic Germans in Eastern Europe who were expelled and repatriated in Germany. See [[German exodus from Eastern Europe]].
